posts.text: My general take is that computer science is the study of generalized problem solving, and software engineering is the art of managing complexity. The fundamental principles that underlie these crafts are broadly applicable across domains, whether someone expects to be writing code or not.

reply_context.text: This is one of the big design choices: can an AI-forward programming class be the first exposure, or is this always setting students up to fail without the basic variables-and-for-loops programmer-thinking class? That one is looking like mostly on-paper, going forward, btw.

reply_context.text: hot take: an introductory class intended for students for whom it will be their first class in a sequence should remain essentiailly unchanged. The fundamentals are still the fundamentals. The difference should be analogous to how presentation of IDE features to intro classes has changed over time.

Talking about AI replacing workers is so broad as to be worthless. ATMs replaced bank tellers and Outlook replaced secretaries being dictated memos by their bosses.

Yet we didnâ€™t talk about them replacing humans. We will see similar dynamics with LLMs. They will take over tasks not entire jobs.
